Learning outcomes: Mathematics as a tool for solving engineering problems
Understanding mathematical formulation of engineering and scientific problems.
Development of basic mathematical knowledge for an engineer.
Description: Differential calculus and integral calculus for functions of one variable with applications
Simple mathematical models in the natural sciences

Learning outcomes: Basic knowledge of linear algebra as a tool for solving engineering problems
Understanding of abstract mathematical formulation of technical and scientific problems
Together with calculus, we develop the basic mathematical knowledge for an engineer
The modelling competence is taught, applied and tested, and the programming competence is applied
Description: Introduction and systems of linear equations
parallel forces and centre of gravity

Learning outcomes: Geology of the Earth
Minerals
Rocks and their cycle
Magmatic rocks
Volcanoes
Weathering
Erosion
Sedimentary rocks
Metamorphic rocks
Historical geology
Structural geology
rock deformation
Landslides
Groundwater
rivers
Wind
glaciers
Processes in the Earth's interior
Earthquakes
Raw materials
Short introduction to the geology of Switzerland
recognize the usefulness and power of computer tools in civil engineering
be prepared to independently use Matlab or Python for solving future problems
explain basic computer science concepts in simple terms
understand and explain the functionality of existing code
analyse a simple civil engineering problem in order to partition it into logical blocks and devise an algorithm to systematically solve the problem
implement simple imperative algorithms in Matlab and Python and explain the functionalities of their code
extend existing code with new functionalities
validate, test and debug their own code as well as existing code
explain the basics of object-oriented and interactive programming
extend existing skeleton code to create simple graphical user interfaces
Description: introduction to interactive programming and graphical user interfaces (GUI)

Learning outcomes: As future construction practitioners, students are able to recognise legal problems independently and in good time in their daily work and to initiate the right measures.
Description: most important legal sources of private construction law

Learning outcomes: Learning to model scientific problems using partial differential equations
developing a good command of the mathematical methods that can be applied to them
knowing the formulation of important problems in science and engineering with a view toward civil engineering
Understanding the properties of the different types of partial differential equations arising in science and in engineering.
Description: Study of the Heat equation general diffusion/parabolic problems using the following tools through Separation of variables as an introduction to Fourier Series
Systematic treatment of the complex and real Fourier Series
Study of the wave equation and general hyperbolic problems using Fourier Series
D'Alembert solution and the method of characteristics
Laplace transform and it's uses to differential equations
Study of the Laplace equation and general elliptic problems using similar tools and generalizations of Fourier series
Application of Laplace transform for beam theory will be discussed

Learning outcomes: In the course Hydraulics I, the competency of process understanding is taught, applied and examined
Furthermore system understanding and measurement methods are taught

Description: balance of linear and angular momentum
balance of linear and angular momentum
Motion of rigid bodies in 2D and 3D
kinematics (angular velocity, velocity and acceleration transfer, instantaneous center and axis of rotation)
balance of linear and angular momentum
single-DOF oscillations (natural frequency, free-, damped-, and forced response)
multi-DOF oscillations (natural frequencies, eigenmodes, free-, damped-, and forced response)
Introduction to waves and vibrations in deformable elastic bodies
local form of linear momentum balance
waves and vibrations in slender elastic rods

Learning outcomes: Understanding the response of elastic beam and frame structures
Ability to correctly apply the equilibrium conditions
Understanding the basics of continuum mechanics
Computation of stresses and deformations of elastic structures
Ability to apply the force (flexibility) method for statically indeterminate structures
Description: Deformations in Euler-Bernoulli and Timoshenko beams

Learning outcomes: Recognition of the basic consequences of the ground construction
Understanding of the important fundamental concepts of Soil mechanics and Geotechnical Engineering
Independent analysis of the basic geotechnical problems
Description: Bearing capacity of shallow and deep foundations
Analysis and design of shallow and deep fondations
Analysis and design of retaining walls

Learning outcomes: Students will expand the knowledge acquired during Steel Structures I and learn how to apply these skills to the design of more complex building and bridge steel and composite structures
They will acquire the fundamental background for the phenomena of plate buckling and fatigue and learn how to apply it to practical design tasks
In addition, students will learn to appreciate the importance of questions of detailling, fabrication, erection and cost calculation for the effective design of steel and composite structures.

After completion of the year-long course in Steel Structures I+II, students will have at their disposal a wide and detailled set of skills concerning the modern practice for steel and composite structures design and have a deep understanding of its theoretical & scientific background

The examples of scientific and standardisation work provided in the lectures give the students the opportunity to learn about the most current developments and see how these are used to shape the future practice in the structural engineering field.
Description: Structural forms, analysis techniques and modelling of multi-storey buildings and bridges
Structural analysis (deformations, internal forces, stresses and strains) in steel-concrete composite girders
effects of creep, shrinkage and shear deformations
Elastic and plastic longitudinal shear transfer mechanisms and effects
Plate buckling of unstiffened and stiffened panels
Fatigue resistance and safe life assessment: phenomenon and design approaches
Special topics of steel connection design
Detailling, drafting, fabrication and erection, cost determination in constructional steelwork

Learning outcomes: Teaches the basic principles of public transport network and topology design
understand the main characteristics and differences of public transport networks, based on buses, railways, or other technologies
recognize the interactions between the infrastructure design and the production processes, and various performance criteria based on various perspective and stakeholders.
critically analyze existing networks of public transport, their design and use
consider and substantiate different choices of technologies to suitable cases
optimize the use of resources in public transport
Description: Infrastructures and vehicle technologies of public transport systems
passengers and goods as infrastructure users
Planning processes and decision levels in network development and infrastructure planning
Fundamentals of the infrastructure design for lines
design and suitability for different goals
conceptual models for passenger transport on long distance

Learning outcomes: how to structure the large amount of information that is often associated with attempting to modify complex systems
how to set goals and define constraints in the engineering of complex systems
how to generate possible solutions to complex problems in ways that limit exceedingly narrow thinking
how to compare multiple possible solutions over time with differences in the temporal distribution of costs and benefits and uncertainty as to what might happen in the future
how to assess values of benefits to stakeholders that are not in monetary units
how to assess whether it is worth obtaining more information in determining optimal solution
how to take a step back from the numbers and qualitatively evaluate the possible solutions in light of the bigger picture

the basics of operations research and how it can be used to determine optimal solutions to complex problems, including linear, integer and network programming, dealing with multiple objectives and conducting sensitivity analyses.
Description: series of methods that range from qualitative and approximate to quantitative and exact
The relationship between net-benefit and the benefit-cost ratio
find optimal solutions to network problems

Learning outcomes: Knowledge of the materials concrete and reinforcing steel and understanding their interaction
Understanding the response of typical structural members
Knowledge of elementary models and ability to apply them to practical problems
Ability to correctly dimension and detail simple structures
Description: strut-and-tie models and simple stress fields

Learning outcomes: first insight into the holistic approach to cope with typical tasks of civil engineering
introduces professional techniques of civil engineering to students
consolidate the knowledge gained so far in bachelor courses
link different domains and to fill gaps with respect to work techniques
analyse the inventory
formulate design requirements and boundary conditions
elaborate approaches and proposals for solutions
dimension some exemplary structural elements
practise detailing and document their work by different media
Description: service criteria agreement and basis of design

Learning outcomes: Mathematics as a tool to solve engineering problems
mathematical formulation of problems in science and engineering
Basic mathematical knowledge of an engineer
The aim of the course is to introduce students to basic tools of statistics and probability theory.
Always related to the field of risk assessment and decision making in engineering, the focus is on the application of the tools and the reasoning behind the application of these disciplines.
Description: Graphical representations (histograms, scatter plots, box plots)

Learning outcomes: the basic concepts of the mechanics of deformable media that they will later apply in other courses such as Dimensioning which are closer to real engineering applications.
Understanding the basic principles of chemistry with particular emphasis on applications in civil engineering.
Description: Corrosion as a system property material/environment

Learning outcomes: work with and to set-up own interactive Python notebooks for their further studies.
apply Python by using the functionality of the most popular modules
overcome implementation and programming language issues to solve simple civil engineering problems.
handle and analyze large datasets and generate high-quality plots.
work with image data for problem analysis.
get a first insight into important applied problems such as simple equilibrium, dynamic, or optimizations problems
explain problem specific solution strategies in simple terms and know about their limitations.
combine building-blocks from the different solution- pipelines to address new questions.
Mastering the methods of analysis for statically indeterminate beam and frame structures
Extending the understanding of the response of beam and frame structures by accounting for plasticity effects
Ability to reasonably interpret and check the results of numerical analyses
Description: Linear analysis of beam and frame structures
Nonlinear analysis of beam and frame structures

Learning outcomes: soil as a multi-phase hydro-mechanical system
essential parameters for classification and description of soil
influence of water on the soil behaviour
stress-strain response and shear-strength of soil
Description: influence of stress history and stress distribution

Learning outcomes: The course introduces the basic theories and methods of transport planning.
Description: Basic theoretical links between transport, space and economic development
measurement and observation of travel behaviour
methods of the four stage approach

Learning outcomes: Getting to know the most important sensors, operation and calculation methods of Geodetic Metrology
Description: Overview on the different domains of geodetic metrology

Learning outcomes: Students understand the basics of steel design, including Stability and stiffness aspects
Main focus is to make visible the background and basic requirements of structural steel design, as well as the interaction between the structural detailing and analytical modelling
Students understand the principals of structural engineering by analysing practical examples of steel structures.
Description: Properties and characteristics of steel and their effects on design

Learning outcomes: Understanding the response of slabs
Knowing the principle and the techniques of prestressing
Ability to correctly dimension and detail typical building structures
Organization of tender documents
Scheduling and cost calculation
Construction methods of Special Underground and Deep Foundation Construction as well as tunnelling methods
Planning of earthwork processes and conception of site logistics
Description: Submission (detailed estimate, special provisions, acceptance standards)
Methods of ground investigation and ground control
Supporting construction methods: soil injection/ jetting
Execution of contruction work und logistics

Learning outcomes: Introduction to the principles of rock mechanics.
Fundamentals of engineering of structures built on rock.
Introduction to planning, design and mechanics of underground structures in rock or soft ground.
Description: Basic phenomena and problems of surface rock engineering and underground rock engineering
recording the interface structure and the mechanical properties of interfaces
influence of water on the interplay of forces
deformation and strength properties of rock
stability of rock slopes and rock foundations
Basic design and project planning of underground structures
Structural systems of traffic tunnelling. System selection
Presentation of appropriate calculation models based on the description and discussion of various phenomena occurring in underground construction
The rock characteristic and the interaction of the rock with the lining
Loosening pressure in rock and loose rock
Stability of the working face in unconsolidated rock
Calculation models for dimensioning the support

Learning outcomes: This course gives the students an overview of topics involved in road transport systems and provides the background for Masters degree study.
Description: operations of private and public transport
management and control of intelligent transportation systems

Learning outcomes: In the course Hydraulic Engineering, the competencies of process understanding and system understanding are taught, applied and examined.
Concept development is taught and applied.
The course aims at knowledge of hydraulic systems and their main hydraulic components and structures
competencies in planning and design of hydraulic structures with regard to serviceability and reliability are teached
Description: Hydraulic systems: High-head storage power plants and low-head run-of-river power plants.
Weirs: weir and gate types, hydraulic design.
Intakes: intake types, desilting facilities and sand traps.
Channels: design, open and closed channels.
Closed conduits: linings, hydraulic design of pressure tunnels and shafts.
Dams and reservoirs: dam types, appurtenant structures
River engineering: flow computation, sediment transport, engineering and environmental measures.
Natural hazards: types, basics of countermeasures
Exercises in written form, exercises in hydraulic and computer laboratory.
